items.title: Crash in 1.3.x when a cmd2.Cmd method is mocked

milestone.description: Bug fix release for CommandSet / subcommands features

items.body:
If you mock a method within a cmd2 which isn't a command or subcommand method using a MagicMock such as with `with mock.patch()` or `with mock.patch.object()`, then things crash because our code thinks it is a subcommand.

Here is a simple unit test that can be added to any of the cmd2 tests files such as **test_cmd2.py** to reproduce this problem:

```Python
class MockMethodApp(cmd2.Cmd):
    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)

    def foo(self):
        pass


def test_mocked_methods():
    with mock.patch.object(MockMethodApp, 'foo'):
        cli = MockMethodApp()
```

And there is the test failure traceback:
```sh
    def test_mocked_methods():
        with mock.patch.object(MockMethodApp, 'foo'):
>           cli = MockMethodApp()

tests/test_cmd2.py:2398: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
tests/test_cmd2.py:2390: in __init__
    super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
cmd2/cmd2.py:415: in __init__
    self._register_subcommands(self)
cmd2/cmd2.py:646: in _register_subcommands
    command_func = self.cmd_func(command_name)
cmd2/cmd2.py:2406: in cmd_func
    func_name = self._cmd_func_name(command)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 

self = <tests.test_cmd2.MockMethodApp object at 0x10c28d8e0>, command = <MagicMock name='foo.parent_command.split().__getitem__()' id='4498776416'>

    def _cmd_func_name(self, command: str) -> str:
        """Get the method name associated with a given command.
    
        :param command: command to look up method name which implements it
        :return: method name which implements the given command
        """
        target = constants.COMMAND_FUNC_PREFIX + command
>       return target if callable(getattr(self, target, None)) else ''
E       TypeError: getattr(): attribute name must be string

cmd2/cmd2.py:2417: TypeError
=============================================================================================== short test summary info ================================================================================================
FAILED tests/test_cmd2.py::test_mocked_methods - TypeError: getattr(): attribute name must be string
```

items.title: Bug in Cmd2HelpFormatter and ArgparseCompleter when metavar is a tuple
items.body:
The [Cmd2HelpFormatter](https://github.com/python-cmd2/cmd2/blob/master/cmd2/argparse_custom.py#L600-L716) class has a bug which causes a crash in the following circumstances:
- `nargs` is an int and > 1
- [metavar](https://docs.python.org/3/library/argparse.html#metavar) is a tuple

Tested with `cmd2` 1.2.0 but verified the bug exists in the current version as well.

In my case, the crash occurs on line 780 in the current code with the [_format_args](https://github.com/python-cmd2/cmd2/blob/master/cmd2/argparse_custom.py#L763-L784) method.

items.title: path_complete doesn't work with CommandSet
items.body:
Version 1.3.0.

When using `path_complete` for a `CommandSet` `argparse` argument the following exception occurs:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/martin/.virtualenvs/pyos/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cmd2/cmd2.py", line 1707, in complete
    self._completion_for_command(text, line, begidx, endidx, shortcut_to_restore)
  File "/home/martin/.virtualenvs/pyos/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cmd2/cmd2.py", line 1592, in _completion_for_command
    self.completion_matches = self._redirect_complete(text, line, begidx, endidx, compfunc)
  File "/home/martin/.virtualenvs/pyos/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cmd2/cmd2.py", line 1385, in _redirect_complete
    return compfunc(text, line, begidx, endidx)
  File "/home/martin/.virtualenvs/pyos/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cmd2/cmd2.py", line 1757, in _complete_argparse_command
    return completer.complete_command(tokens_to_parse, text, line, begidx, endidx, cmd_set=cmd_set)
  File "/home/martin/.virtualenvs/pyos/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cmd2/argparse_completer.py", line 429, in complete_command
    completion_results = self._complete_for_arg(pos_arg_state.action, text, line,
  File "/home/martin/.virtualenvs/pyos/lib/python3.8/site-packages/cmd2/argparse_completer.py", line 596, in _complete_for_arg
    results = arg_choices.to_call(*args, **kwargs)
TypeError: path_complete() takes 5 positional arguments but 6 were given
```

This happens because the `CommandSet` is being passed in as the second positional argument which isn't expected by the completer.

A big benefit of completers is that they can be used by disparate commands (whether they be free functions later bound to a `Cmd` class, members of a `Cmd` class or members of a `CommandSet`).  Having a different interface detracts from this as, now, something like a shim is required to make it work without redefining a new `path_complete`.

I think it's worth considering ways to have a common interface, not only for the complete functions but for `do` and `help`.  A couple of suggestions come to mind:

1.

`def path_complete(self, text: str, line: str, begidx: int, endidx: int, context)`

where `context` is a dict or `namedtuple` that stores a reference to the `Cmd` instance and (optionally) the `CommandSet`.

2.

Both `Cmd` and `CommandSet` conform to a common interface that specifies the subset of things that can be done by both (most methods/attributes from `Cmd`), and `CommandSet` just forwards these to its `_cmd` member.

items.title: Validate Python 3.5.2/3.5.3 support before ending support for 3.5
items.body: Python 3.5.3 is the last version officially supported on Debian 9 and 3.5.2 is the last officially supported version on Ubuntu 16.04. Let's validate everything against 3.5.2/3.5.3 one last time before cutting support completely.

items.title: Deprecate `with_argparser_and_unknown_args` and add `with_unknown` parameter to `with_argparser`
items.body:
Other than 2 lines, `with_argparser_and_unknown_args` is identical to `with_argparser`.

Suggest deprecating `with_argparser_and_unknown_args` and adding an optional parameter of `with_argparser`.

As a transitional near-term solution, we can just add the new parameter to `with_argparser` and change `with_argparser_and_unknown_args` to just call the common implementation.

items.title: Registering a preloop hook without return type hint throws an error
items.body:
As is discussed [here](https://cmd2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/features/hooks.html?highlight=preloop#application-lifecycle-hooks), I should be able to declare and register a preloop hook as follows:

```
class App(cmd2.Cmd):
    def __init__(self, *args, *kwargs):
        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.register_preloop_hook(self.myhookmethod)

    def myhookmethod(self):
        self.poutput("before the loop begins")
```

However, running the above will throw an error: ```TypeError: initialize_preloop must declare return a return type of 'None'```. In order to fix the error, you need to provide a return type hint:

```
class App(cmd2.Cmd):
    def __init__(self, *args, *kwargs):
        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.register_preloop_hook(self.myhookmethod)

    def myhookmethod(self) -> None:
        self.poutput("before the loop begins")
```

Versions:
- cmd2: 1.2.0
- python: 3.7

items.title: usage of typing.Deque breaks compatibility
items.body:
The new TableCreator uses typing.Dequeue, which was added in Python 3.5.4. We currently declare we support 3.5.0 and higher. Debian Stretch maxes out python3 support at Python 3.5.3 so we currently don't support Debian Stretch users and we don't support the versions of python we're currently publishing.

Suggestions:
- We should probably have one of the test variations run on the oldest version we say we support so this gets caught in the future.
- Until we drop support for Python 3.5, we can change the type declaration to be by string.

items.title: Invalid commands and using python builtin 'input()' leaves incorrect text in command history
items.body:
From the docs:

> cmd2 only saves input to internal history if the command parses successfully and is a valid command.

Also, after discussing it with @anselor, my understanding is that if there is a command that uses python's builtin `input()` to get user input for a command, the actual text input at the prompt should not be included in cmd2's command history. 

In both cases, an invalid command and `input()` text, seem to be saved to the command history using version cmd2 1.0.2 on python 3.7.1.

If I have a single command `test` defined, even if I enter an invalid command `something`, something appears in my command history:
```
(Cmd) something
something is not a recognized command, alias, or macro
(reverse-i-search)`some': something
```

Likewise, if the command uses python's `input()` function, any text entered at the prompt will also appear in the history:
```
(Cmd) test
Enter some text: something typed
You entered 'something typed'. Check your history.
(reverse-i-search)`som': something typed
```

Attached is a working example as a text file since apparently github doesn't allow `.py` files.

[__main__.txt](https://github.com/python-cmd2/cmd2/files/4619824/__main__.txt)

items.title: Version 1.0.2 changed the way SystemExit exceptions raised from do_command methods are handled
items.body:
I have a cmd2 application which does it's own argparsing inside of the `do_command()` methods, i.e. it does not use any of the cmd2 built-in arg parsing functionality. This is done by calling `argparse.parse_args()` as one of the first lines of code inside the `do_command()` method.

In 1.0.1 if a `do_command()` method raises a `SystemExit` exception, as `parse_args()` does if given the '-h' option or if a syntax error occurs, that exception would be swallowed by `cmd2` and the command prompt would be printed again.

In 1.0.2, that exception is not swallowed and the `cmd2` app terminates.

You can replicate this issue by adding a `raise SystemExit` to the `do_speak()` method in `examples/first_app.py`, and running it with the two versions of `cmd2`.

The behavior of other raised exceptions does not appear to have changed between 1.0.1 and 1.0.2. For example if you raise a ValueError, you get:
```
EXCEPTION of type 'ValueError' occurred with message: ''
To enable full traceback, run the following command: 'set debug true'
```
in both versions of `cmd2`.

This change in behavior is caused by the change in the logic on the last two lines of the `onecmd_plus_hooks()` method made between 1.0.1 and 1.0.2.

In the short term, I request that we quickly revert this change in behavior. After that, I suggest we discuss the desired behavior is for `cmd2` when a `SystemExit` exception is raised, and then intentionally implement and document that behavior.

items.title: test_which_editor_good (obviously) fails on systems without vi installed
items.body:
See also: https://bugs.gentoo.org/710174#c1

Long story short, it is very wrong to assume that `vi` will exist. Firstly, because there are Linux distributions where vi is not even part of default package set. Gentoo, for example, requires 'some' editor to exist, and defaults to nano. Secondly, because it is entirely valid to have vim installed without 'vi' symlink.

If you want to rely on some specific tool being available, I would suggest using something from base POSIX set.

items.title: Allow passing extra args to **do_** functions
items.body:
Please allow passing extra args to **do_** functions

In this example, I add __**kwargs__ to the decorator.

```python
def with_argparser(parser: argparse.ArgumentParser, *,
                   ns_provider: Optional[Callable[..., argparse.Namespace]] = None,
                   preserve_quotes: bool = False) -> Callable[[argparse.Namespace], Optional[bool]]:
    """A decorator to alter a cmd2 method to populate its ``args`` argument by parsing arguments
    with the given instance of argparse.ArgumentParser.

    :param parser: unique instance of ArgumentParser
    :param ns_provider: An optional function that accepts a cmd2.Cmd object as an argument and returns an
                        argparse.Namespace. This is useful if the Namespace needs to be prepopulated with
                        state data that affects parsing.
    :param preserve_quotes: if True, then arguments passed to argparse maintain their quotes
    :return: function that gets passed the argparse-parsed args in a Namespace
             A member called __statement__ is added to the Namespace to provide command functions access to the
             Statement object. This can be useful if the command function needs to know the command line.

    :Example:

    >>> parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    >>> parser.add_argument('-p', '--piglatin', action='store_true', help='atinLay')
    >>> parser.add_argument('-s', '--shout', action='store_true', help='N00B EMULATION MODE')
    >>> parser.add_argument('-r', '--repeat', type=int, help='output [n] times')
    >>> parser.add_argument('words', nargs='+', help='words to print')
    >>>
    >>> class MyApp(cmd2.Cmd):
    >>>     @cmd2.with_argparser(parser, preserve_quotes=True)
    >>>     def do_argprint(self, args):
    >>>         "Print the options and argument list this options command was called with."
    >>>         self.poutput('args: {!r}'.format(args))
    """
    import functools

    def arg_decorator(func: Callable):
        @functools.wraps(func)
        def cmd_wrapper(cmd2_app, statement: Union[Statement, str], **kwargs):
            statement, parsed_arglist = cmd2_app.statement_parser.get_command_arg_list(command_name,
                                                                                       statement,
                                                                                       preserve_quotes)

            if ns_provider is None:
                namespace = None
            else:
                namespace = ns_provider(cmd2_app)

            try:
                args = parser.parse_args(parsed_arglist, namespace)
            except SystemExit:
                raise Cmd2ArgparseError
            else:
                setattr(args, '__statement__', statement)
                return func(cmd2_app, args, **kwargs)

        # argparser defaults the program name to sys.argv[0], but we want it to be the name of our command
        command_name = func.__name__[len(constants.COMMAND_FUNC_PREFIX):]
        _set_parser_prog(parser, command_name)

        # If the description has not been set, then use the method docstring if one exists
        if parser.description is None and func.__doc__:
            parser.description = func.__doc__

        # Set the command's help text as argparser.description (which can be None)
        cmd_wrapper.__doc__ = parser.description

        # Set some custom attributes for this command
        setattr(cmd_wrapper, constants.CMD_ATTR_ARGPARSER, parser)
        setattr(cmd_wrapper, constants.CMD_ATTR_PRESERVE_QUOTES, preserve_quotes)

        return cmd_wrapper

    # noinspection PyTypeChecker
    return arg_decorator
```

**run_pyscript** now call like this:
```
self.do_stuff("arg1 --xxx --yyy hhh", stuff=True)
```

To do the same thing without **kwargs**, actually I must pass arguments like that:
```python
parser.add_argument('--stuff', action='store_true', help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
self.do_stuff("search xx --stuff")
```

items.title: Fix Sphinx 3.0.0 autodoc warnings
items.body:
Sphinx 3.0.0 was released on April 5, 2020 and it has some significant improvements such as automatically adding links to classes specific in type hints in autodoc API documentation .

However, at least at this time this ends up generating a ton of warnings because it can't find documentation for classes, especially ones from the `typing` module.

One way around this is to add ` `nitpick_ignore` to the **docs/config.py** file like so:
```Python
# Ignore nitpicky warnings from autodoc which are occurring for very new versions of Sphinx and autodoc
# They seem to be happening because autodoc is now trying to add hyperlinks to docs for typehint classes
nitpick_ignore = [
    ('py:class', 'Callable[[None], None]'),
    ('py:class', 'cmd2.cmd2.Cmd'),
    ('py:class', 'cmd2.parsing.Statement'),
    ('py:class', 'IO'),
    ('py:class', 'None'),
    ('py:class', 'Union[None, Iterable, Callable]'),
]
```

But this would actually need to be significantly longer than shown above.

I'm not sure if there is a better approach.  Temporarily, we could limit to Sphinx <= 2.4.4 if we just need to stop the bleeding of failed doc builds and such.

items.title: Postcommand Hooks and argparse
items.body:
Hi

I am using argparse for autocompletion and with sub-commands. 
I always annotate my command methods with `@with_argparser(parser)` which i think is the right way to use the argparser with cmd2. 
I did experiment with postcommand hooks using the `register_postcmd_hook` method. 
The documentation states, that the registered postcommand is only executed when the command method was called (in case of a raised exception the postcommand it is not executed). 

Now, if argparse can't parse the submitted args (for example when there are too few), the command method is not executed, but the postcommand hooks will be executed anyway. 

I understand, that in this context, the `@with_argparser(parser)` belongs to the method and thus one could argument, the method was called and didn't raise an exception, but on the other side, in most cases (i think), it makes not a lot of sense to execute postcommands if argparse can't parse the arguments of the command method. 
Is this behaviour intended? And if yes, is there a possibility to change it? I know i could ditch the annotations, use the argparser inside the command method and raise an exception if argparse fails, but this seems to be a lot of overhead (and i would lose the autocomplete stuff).

Could i possibly "monkey patch" the `with_argparser` method so a exception will be raised? (Also not a very elegant solution i think)

Thanks for any help.

items.title: Should we implement hook methods from `cmd.Cmd` so we can document them?
items.body:
We are not consistent in defining and documenting methods from `cmd.Cmd` which we use/rely-on, but which perform the same function as they do in our superclass. For example, `cmd2.Cmd` provides an implementation of the `precmd()` method from our superclass, which does exactly the same thing as the superclass method. We do not implement `postcmd()` or `preloop()` or `postloop()`, which are no-ops in the superclass, i.e. they are stub methods waiting to be over-ridden.

Providing an implementation of these methods allows us to reference them in our documentation, which is nice.

I don't care whether we do or don't provide an implementation for these methods, but whichever we choose, we ought to do it the same for all four of these hook-type methods.

Any preference?

items.title: Re-evaluate visibility of EmptyStatement exception
items.body:
In `cmd2.py` we define an `EmptyStatement` exception. In `__init__.py` we import that exception, making it available as `cmd2.EmptyStatement`. As far as I can tell, we only use this exception for internal purposes: no methods available as part of our public API throw this exception.

If this is true, then it seem like:

1. We shouldn't document `EmptyStatement` as part of our public API, and
2. We should remove the package level import of `EmptyStatement` from `__init__.py`.

What do you think?

items.title: API Documentation Approach
items.body:
I've been working on the API documentation. We have lots of constants, functions, and classes which we use internally and which are not really intended to be part of the public API. For example, in `constants.py` the `COMMAND_FUNC_PREFIX` constant is only for internal use.

Somewhere/somehow we need to indicate whether this item is part of the public API. We could:

1. Go through a renaming exercise and rename everything that isn't public to start with an underscore.
2. Declare that the documentation, not the source code, is the authoritative declaration of the public api.
2a. Don't use the `:members:` Sphinx directive; it will include everything that doesn't start with an underscore. Instead, individually add methods, functions, and constants that are part of the public API to the documentation. This is how `decorators.py` is built now. It's OK when there are only a handful of items, but it would be quite unwieldy for `cmd2.Cmd`, which has nearly a hundred methods.
2b. I haven't experimented with this, but we could use something like https://public.readthedocs.io/en/latest/README.html, a decorator which magically populates `__all__`, and which it appears that the Sphinx `:members:` directive honors.
2c. Wait for Sphinx 3.0 to be released, which includes a `:meta private:` info field. By adding this to the docstring of a method, you can tell Sphinx that it's private and it will be excluded from `:members:`.

The nice thing about 1 is that it's abundantly clear from the source code what's public and what isn't. This makes it more visible when modifying or enhancing so a developer can be more thoughtful about breaking changes. The downside to renaming everything is that the potential for breaking downstream consumers is high.

If we choose the documentation to be the definition of the public API, then we have to manually include or exclude items when creating and maintaining the documentation.

If there is single function in a module that we don't want to be public, and which doesn't begin with an underscore, we can't use the sphinx `:members:` directive to generate the documentation, we will have to list all the functions out one by one. For example, I could argue that the `cmd_func()` method in the `cmd2.Cmd` class should not be part of the public API. If we decided that it shouldn't be, then when building and maintaining the documentation for the `cmd2.Cmd` class you have to manually create a list of the approx 100 other methods in that class instead of just putting `:members:`

This seems like a bit of work, but doable. To reduce that work we could experiment with some sort of `@public` decorator, or wait for Sphinx 3.0 (who know how long that will be) and exclude things using the private info field in the docstrings.

Any preferences on what to do here?

items.title: setting settable attribute with default type None does not change

milestone.description: Stable 1.0.0 release ready for wide usage

items.body:
It appears that when a `settable` attribute is set that a call to `utils.cast` is made and attempts to cast the new `value` to the type of `orig_value`. When the original value is `None` the result of that value is also `None` and, in my case, gets passed to my setter as `None`.

While I understand that this could easily resolved by setting the default value of my attribute to '', it visually looks odd when every other settable is filled besides the one that was not set.

``` text
...
allow_style: Terminal
att: 
continuation_prompt: > 
...
```

Likewise, setting the default value to `'None'` does not seem like a good answer to resolving the issue. 

In this particular case, I think I would prefer if the original value is 'None' then the str that was passed is set

items.title: Consider making help -v more discoverable

milestone.description: Stable 1.0.0 release ready for wide usage

items.body:
Consider rewording the default help text to make `help -v` more discoverable.

Currently the beginning output of the **help** command is:
```sh
Documented commands (type help <topic>):
```

It might provide a better user experience if we made `help -v` more discoverable by rewording this to something like:
```sh
Documented commands (type help -v for verbose summary or help <topic> for details):
```

items.title: Does the edit command provide value?

milestone.description: Stable 1.0.0 release ready for wide usage

items.body:
I did a quick audit of the built-in `cmd2` commands with an eye towards whether or not they should exist in a generic framework for interactive command-line applications.  Nearly all of the commands feel like they provide specific value.

The one I am questioning is **edit**.  Since we can run arbitrary shell commands, it is trivial to open any editor on the user's path to edit any file on their path so I don't necessarily see a value other than for users who don't know the name of an editor.  Maybe that is worthwhile.  Maybe not.  I would like to solicit other opinions in regards to whether or not we should leave this in as a built-in command.

Also, if we do decide to keep the **edit** command it currently allows us to call the edit command without a file path.  However if we open an editor in this fashion, we can't save our edits.  That doesn't seem to be useful at all.  If we do leave **edit** in, should we make the `file_path` argument required?

@kmvanbrunt @kotfu @anselor 
If any of you have an opinion on this, please state it.  All other users of ``cmd2`` are more than welcome to chime in as well.

P.S.  I am also slightly questioning the value of the **py** command given that we have an optional **ipy** and a **run_pyscript** for running Python scripts.  It does seem like it provides some value for very uncommon use cases.  But I'm not sure it makes sense to leave it in generically to satisfy those rare use cases.  So I would welcome opinions in regards to the usefulness (or lack thereof) of **py** in addition to **edit**.

items.title: Simple Dynamic Autocomplete
Reconsider which attributes should be settable by default

milestone.description: Stable 1.0.0 release ready for wide usage

items.body:
Anything which is settable by using the **set** command can easily be changed at runtime by end users.

I'm wondering if we might provide a better end-user experience by leaving these attributes out of the `settable` dictionary by default:

- continuation_prompt
- locals_in_py
- prompt

My reasoning is that for `prompt` and `continuation_prompt` - altering the changes the look and feel of an application and also might possibly have unintended consequences.    While for `locals_in_py`, developers might not want their end users to be able to easily enable this at runtime.

items.title: Exclude docs and a few other things from the PyPI package
items.body:
I took a quick look at what is actually in our [latest PyPI package](https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/03/9d/55b88a06ecc28ba4378b1747311cce30d936325f6f3992ed49e539c56507/cmd2-0.9.24.tar.gz):
```sh
CHANGELOG.md         CONTRIBUTING.md      PKG-INFO             azure-pipelines.yml  cmd2.png             setup.cfg            tests/
CODEOWNERS           LICENSE              Pipfile              cmd2/                docs/                setup.py*            tox.ini
CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md   MANIFEST.in          README.md*           cmd2.egg-info/       examples/            tasks.py
```

Things which probably shouldn't be there include:
* .appveyor.yml
* .coveragerc
* .gitignore
* .travis.yml
* CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
* Pipfile
* azure-pipelines.yml
* docs/
* tasks.py

These should be excludable by modifying the **MANIFEST.in** file and adding lines like:
```sh
recursive-exclude docs
```

items.title: Implicit dependency on setuptools is missing
items.body: `cmd2` has an implicit runtime dependency on `setuptools` due to use of `setuptools_scm` for versioning.  However, we don't explicitly call out this dependency in **setup.py**.  This could present a problem on any system which doesn't have `setuptools` installed.

items.title: Easier way to define parsers with dynamic argument choices
items.body:
What I want to be able to do is define a function that takes certain state variables and generates a parser that will be used for cmd2 commands so that, based on the state, certain argparser arguments may have different choices. Doing that is not possible with the current with_argparser* decorators exposed in cmd2, so I'm stuck with managing the parsing in the do_CMDNAME method for now to accomplish my task. I looked into trying to decorate the with_argparser* decorators in a way that would take the state variables, but that gets awkward pretty quickly since the objects that I would want to pass wouldn't exist until the cmd2 object is already initialized. 

So I'm sure there a few ways to more cleanly solve this problem. One way in particular that I've always wished was possible with argparser/cmd2 was to pass arguments and a function for choices that dynamically returns the choices. For this to work though, I'd have to also be able to define 'choice_arguments' or whatever you may better call such a field where you can pass a list of things to be passed to the function when it is run to evaluate the choices.

items.title: ArgumentParser changes between 0.9.11 and 0.9.21
items.body:
Hello! I'm trying to understand the differences in how ArgumentParsers are defined and used in this new form as I am trying to update a project. My cmd2 app (using cmd2 0.9.11) uses the following structure: ```python def MyClass(cmd2.Cmd): ... parser = argparse_completer.ACArgumentParser() setattr(filter_create_sp.add_argument("my_arg"), argparse_completer.ACTION_ARG_CHOICES, ("_my_completer_function",)) @cmd2.with_argparser(parser) def do_command(self, args): ... ``` where `_my_completer_function` is a method of the `MyClass` class.
My understanding is that the new format of this code is something along the lines of: ```python def MyClass(cmd2.Cmd): ... parser = cmd2.argparse_custom.Cmd2ArgumentParser() parser.add_argument("my_arg", choices_method=self._my_completer_function) @cmd2.with_argparser(parser) def do_command(self, args): .... ``` Unfortunately, I cannot work out how to pass/use `self`(or other reference to the instance of my cmd2 app) for the `parser.add_argument("my_arg", choices_method=self._my_completer_function)` line. I need the `MyClass` instance to be passed to my custom completer function. Am I missing something obvious? Thanks in advance.

items.title: utils.center_text() is not ansi aware

items.title: Documenting Attributes
items.body:
As I work on writing documentation, I have come across the following situation:

1. We have many attributes, especially in `cmd2.Cmd`, which impact the behavior of the application, for the purposes of this example, let's use `broken_pipe_warning`.
2. These attributes should be treated as part of the public API that `cmd2` offers to developers.
3. We reference these attributes and their behavior when writing about features or in examples.
4. It's desirable to have these references link to our API documentation, which is generated from source code
5. You can put a docstring on the line after an attribute, and Sphinx will pick it up, but that only works if the attribute is defined on the class, outside of the `_init_` method. For example, Sphinx picks up the docstring for `NATURAL_SORT_KEY`, but not for `broken_pipe_warning`

To fix this issue, I propose the following and invite discussion, feedback, and alternative solutions:

1. All class attributes that are intended to be part of the "public interface" should be implemented as properties, using `@property` (and friends) decorators for the getter and setter methods.
2. The attribute/property is documented in the docstring of the getter method.

See the API documentation for `allow_ansi` for an example of how this works. I believe this proposal offers 2 benefits, with no downsides.

1. It forces us to clarify and document the public API of our module, especially the `cmd2.Cmd` class.
2. It makes it easy to generate and reference the API documentation for the attributes

Because Python properties and their getter/setter methods behave exactly as attributes, there will be no disruption to consumers of our library.

What do you think of this proposal?

items.title: Overriding ansi.style_error()
items.body:
While working on documentation for using ansi color support, I noticed that `ansi.py` defines three convenience methods for styling output:

- `style_success()`
- `style_warning()`
- `style_error()`

These methods are all [partial objects](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functools.html#functools.partial) created with `functools.partial()` which supply certain arguments to `style()`. These methods all behave similarly, I'll give an example for `style_error()`, but the concept applies to the other methods too.

`ansi.style_error()` adds ANSI escape sequences to style the message as red text. Say I am creating my own `cmd2` based app, and I am following our recommendations to use `perror()` to output error messages. But I decide in my app I want my error messages to have a yellow background with red text. There are two ways for me to accomplish my objective:

1. override the `perror()` method and change the styling applied to the message. The problem with this method is that there are a couple of places in `argparse_completer.py` and `argparse_custom.py` that call `ansi.style_error()` directly, so those error messages won't match my application's custom error message style.

2. redefine `ansi.style_error()` so it uses my custom error message color scheme. This makes error messages consistent, but is very brittle and can make my application hard to debug.

Should we consider a different implementation of the "standardizing error, warning, and success text styling" idea that makes it easier for an app developer to override the text coloring we choose to use in `cmd2`?

One possible approach would be to move `style_error()` from a function in `ansi.py` to a method on `Cmd2.cmd`.

items.title: pwarning() should have an apply_style argument
items.body: `perror()` and `pexcept()` both have an `apply_style` argument which defaults to `True`. If that argument is `True`, then the method applies an ansi style to the message before sending it to the output stream. `pwarning()`` always applies the style. It should have an `apply_style` argument like it's sister methods.

items.title: pfeedback() needs similar arguments as poutput()
items.body: the `pfeedback()` method only accepts one argument, the string to output. All of our other output methods like `poutput()`, `perror()`, etc. take an `end` argument which defaults to `\n`. We should add this argument to `pfeedback()` too.

items.title: Getting "stty: stdin isn't a terminal" errors when piping input to my app
items.body:
I have a ``cmd2`` based app which can accept commands piped via stdin, like so:
```
$ echo some_command | my_app
```

When used in this way, I get the following error:

"stty: stdin isn't a terminal"

I believe this error is caused by a bug in the ``_run_cmdfinalization_hooks()`` method of ``cmd2.Cmd``. If stdout is a tty, and we are not on windows, it runs ``stty sane``, which generates this error message.

items.title: Help Scoping
items.body:
I am working on building an application using cmd2.  I am struggling to understand how to control scoping on help text.  When I create a command that uses arguments, good to go.  For a command that when fully provided looks like this: ```root_cmd sub_cmd sub_cmd_argument```, if sub_cmd_argument is missing, I get this:
```
> root_cmd sub_cmd
Error: the following arguments are required: sub_cmd_argument
```
Perfect.

But when a subcommand argument is missing, it gives me the help text for the outer-most command.  So for a command that when fully provided looks like this: ```root_cmd sub_cmd sub_cmd2```, if sub_cmd2 is missing, I get this:
```
> root_cmd sub_cmd
This is the help for root_cmd
```
But what I really want in this case is:
```
> root_cmd sub_cmd
This is the help for sub_cmd
```

How do I accomplish this?

Python version = 3.6
OS name and version = Windows 10
What you did to cause the bug to occur = A history file that was created by an old version of cmd2 (<=0.9.14) caused an exception during initialization and the upgraded cmd2 crashed

Include any traceback or error message associated with the bug = 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\mattthk4\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "C:\Users\mattthk4\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python36\lib\runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "C:\Users\mattthk4\cvenv\Scripts\cdata-cli.exe\__main__.py", line 9, in <module>
  File "c:\users\mattthk4\cvenv\lib\site-packages\cbash\cdata_cli.py", line 1193, in main
    app = CmdLineApp(debug=args.debug)
  File "c:\users\mattthk4\cvenv\lib\site-packages\cbash\cdata_cli.py", line 274, in __init__
    cmd2.Cmd.__init__(self, persistent_history_file=self.HIST_FILE)
  File "c:\users\mattthk4\cvenv\lib\site-packages\cmd2\cmd2.py", line 429, in __init__

    history = pickle.load(fobj)
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'et projects --p\n'
```

Cause: The call to pickle.load() in cmd2._initialize_history() failed to catch the ValueError exception.

Solution: Add ValueError in the list of non-operating system error/exception to catch.

Proposed changes:

```
diff --git a/cmd2/cmd2.py b/cmd2/cmd2.py
index 5e1f9a7..5831053 100644
--- a/cmd2/cmd2.py
+++ b/cmd2/cmd2.py

         try:
             with open(hist_file, 'rb') as fobj:
                 history = pickle.load(fobj)
-        except (AttributeError, EOFError, FileNotFoundError, ImportError, IndexError, KeyError, pickle.UnpicklingError):
+        except (AttributeError, EOFError, FileNotFoundError, ImportError, IndexError, KeyError, pickle.UnpicklingError, ValueError):
             # If any non-operating system error occurs when attempting to unpickle, just use an empty history
             pass
         except OSError as ex:
```

items.title: Add method to know if you are in a script
items.body:
I frequently use command finalization hooks to print something just before returning to the prompt. I don't want the output to occur after each command running in a Python or text script though.

Currently I do the following to know if I'm in a script:
```Python
if self._in_py or self._current_script_dir is not None:
    # In script
````

It would be better to provide developers with a method so they don't have to reference protected members.

items.title: Create cmd2-specific input() function
items.body:
Provide developers a function for reading input with the following signature:

`def read_input(self, prompt: str, enable_completion: bool = False) -> str`

The name isn't set in stone.

Difference between this function and the existing `_pseudo_read_input`

1. Raises `EOFError` exceptions instead returning the string `eof`
2. Turns off tab completion by default

`_pseudo_read_input` will be replaced by something similar to the following:

```Python
def _read_command_line(self, prompt: str) -> str:
    try:
        # Wrap in try since terminal_lock may not be locked
        try:
            # Command line is about to be drawn. Allow asynchronous changes to the terminal.
            self.terminal_lock.release()
        except RuntimeError:
            pass
        return self.read_input(prompt, enable_completion=True)
    except EOFError:
        return 'eof'
    finally:
        # Command line is gone. Do not allow asynchronous changes to the terminal.
        self.terminal_lock.acquire()
```

items.title: Handle mutually exclusive group in AutoCompleter
items.body:
AutoCompleter should be improved to keep track of what arg was used in a mutually exclusive group and not offer to tab complete the other args in the group.

While these groups typically just include flags, it is possible to a have a positional as in the following case.

```Python
parser = Cmd2ArgumentParser()

group = parser.add_mutually_exclusive_group(required=True)
group.add_argument('optional_pos', nargs=argparse.OPTIONAL) 
group.add_argument('--flag')

parser.add_argument('required_pos')
```

If `--flag` had been used, then AutoCompleter would need to skip over `optional_pos` to `required_pos`.

items.title: Remove support for use_rawinput
items.body:

See #206 for a previous reference to this issue.

items.title: Allow to dynamically extend a cmd2.Cmd object with a custom do_xxx method at runtime.
items.body:
Issue #267 also addresses the same issue.

Extending the `cmd2.Cmd` object with `do_xxx` perhaps might not be the what most users what.
But since the solution is simple and is not an API breaking change, I thought I would mention it anyway. This approach also seems more reasonable than the current method.

As noted in the earlier issue, the main issue is that the `do_xxx` methods are not registered in the help menu. Perhaps a minor oversight from Cpython cmd developers (since this is a minor issue that can be fixed by extending the class), but `dir(self.__class__)` doesn't account for the functions added at runtime.

A simple fix would be to override the `get_names()` in `cmd2.Cmd` to change the default implementation (from [cpython's source](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/cmd.py#L281))
```python
 def get_names(self):
        return dir(self.__class__)
``` 
into 
```python
def get_names(self):
        return dir(self)
```


I believe **making this minor change would allow users to extend the cmd2 module at runtime**. :)

items.title: Allow customization of the default argument parser used by cmd2
items.body:
We have the ability to modify the argument parser used by `do_XX` commands with `@with_parser` decorator.

The parsers used by the inbuilt cmd2 commands such as `macro`, `alias` etc are hardcoded to use `Cmd2ArgumentParser`
https://github.com/python-cmd2/cmd2/blob/master/cmd2/cmd2.py#L2384

Since I have my custom argument parser for all my `do_XX` commands (which inherits from Cmd2ArgumentParser), the output of my custom commands while parsing commands (color/format) doesn't match with the output of the default commands like `alias`, `macro`.

Currently, I have a class similar to,

````python

class CustomCmd2(cmd2.Cmd):
    def __init__(self, connection, *args, **kwargs):
        # Dynamically add all do_XX functions from the package 'modules' since it is cumbersome
        # to write every method in the class.
        for module_name in modules.__all__:
            module = importlib.import_module(modules.__name__ + "." + module_name)
            predicate = lambda obj: inspect.isfunction(obj) and obj.__name__.startswith("do_")
            functions = inspect.getmembers(module, predicate)
            for function_name, function in functions:
                setattr(self, function_name, types.MethodType(function, self))

        cmd2.Cmd.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)

        # Modify the parsers after initialization.
        # Cast the parser to my custom parser for added functionality.
        def cast(obj, req_type, obj_type = None):
            if obj_type:
                assert isinstance(self.alias_parser, obj_type), "The object type is different. Dangerous to  cast."
            obj.__class__ = req_type

        cast(self.alias_parser, ColoredArgParser, cmd2.Cmd2ArgumentParser)
        .........

    def get_names(self):
        """
        The default implementation from cmd (cpython implementation) looks like,
            def get_names(self):
                return dir(self.__class__)
        Since we are modifying the class instance so that functions are added at runtime, we have to return dir(self)
        This fixes the issue of the commands not registering in do_help().
        """
        return dir(self) 
````

To change the default parser to my custom ColoredArgParser, I am hacking the class with,

```python
def obj_cast(obj, req_type, obj_type = None):
    if obj_type:
        assert isinstance(self.alias_parser, obj_type), "The object type is different. Dangerous to  cast."
    obj.__class__ = req_type

obj_cast(self.alias_parser, ColoredArgParser, cmd2.Cmd2ArgumentParser)

```

This seems very hackish, and casting is not pythonic.
I believe there should be a way to specify the default argument parser used.

This would also match the API used in the rest of the project.
We have the ability to modify the HelpFormatter in cmd2 https://github.com/python-cmd2/cmd2/blob/master/cmd2/argparse_custom.py#L694
There must also be a way to modify the default argument parser.
Maybe in a similar fashion while constructing the object?

If there is a simpler way to achieve this, it would be helpful to know the method.
I am willing to contribute if necessary.

items.title: disable_command() throws exception if None passed as message
items.body:
The disable_command() method requires a `message_to_print` parameter. If the user tries to run a disabled command, the value of this string is displayed for the user. There is no way for the developer to disable a command without printing a message. You can set this parameter to an empty string, but then a blank line is output when the user tries to run the command.

We should make this parameter optional and default to `None`. If set to `None`, nothing should be printed when the user tries to run a disabled command.

items.title: Alias and Macro names
items.body:
It has been brought to my attention by another developer that allowing aliases and macros to share names with commands could cause issues with users being unwise. Specifically he said:

> being able to create an alias that overrides/hides a command is bad for usability

Currently we have the following restrictions:

1. Alias cannot share its name with a macro
2. Macro cannot share its name with an alias or a multiline command

When I first wrote aliases, I did prevent them from sharing their name with a command. Then I decided to remove this restriction to be like bash. However, in bash you can still call the original command if you know its path. (e.g. /bin/ls). **cmd2** does not work in the same way since our commands are not executable files somewhere on disk.

I'm OK adding the restriction back, but I would like some consensus on the issue. And I really don't want the answer to be, "add a flag".

@kotfu @tleonhardt @anselor What are your thoughts?

items.title: Purpose of allow_redirection
items.body:
What is `allow_redirection` supposed to do? Is it there only to prevent redirection of stdout or is it also intended to alter parsing behavior?

When set to **False,** it slightly, but not completely, alters parsing.
- `command > out.txt` results in `command `
- `command >out.txt` results in `command  >out.txt`

If  `allow_redirection` is False, should we treat redirectors as literals or preserve normal parsing behavior and just consider `allow_redirection` to be a security setting?

See #15 and #45 for some context.

items.title: Determine future branching strategy
items.body:
When we get to 1.0.0 and are ready to really do semantic versioning, our current branch/merge approach will not be sufficient. After 1.0.0 is tagged, we could have potentially three active development branches:

- 1.0.1
- 1.1.0
- 2.0.0

We will need to rethink how we use **master**. Maybe we need to only merge to master when we cut a release, so **master** HEAD contains the most "recent" (according to semver) release. We probably will also need to start using a **develop** branch as a place to integrated all the hotfix, minor (i.e. 1.x.0) and major (i.e. x.0.0) branches.

We are not the first people to have to solve this problem, after a little digging, I found
[Hendrick Prinsloo's description of his approach](https://medium.com/@HendrikPrinsZA/gitflow-with-semver-dde625429aca). I think this is a reasonably sound method, and propose that we adopt it.

Opinions and debate welcome.

- alias and macro lists

items.title: Revise Documentation Structure
items.body:
Related to #572, I propose an overhaul of the documentation. I intend for this issue to be the place where we discuss and agree on a high level structure and some guiding principles for the documentation. The writing of the various parts which don't yet exist can be handled in other issues.

## Guiding Principles

- We have gone to great lengths to retain compatibility with the standard library `cmd`, the documentation should make it easy for developers to understand how to move from `cmd` to `cmd2`, and what benefits that will provide
- We should provide both descriptive and reference documentation.
- API reference documentation should be generated from docstrings in the code
- Documentation should include rich hyperlinking to other areas of the documentation, and to the API reference

## High Level Structure

Here's a proposed top level outline for the documentation. I'm not proposing and order yet, just an unsorted list of high level topics.

- Overview
    - what cmd2 is, major features for users and developers, and what it isn't
    - Quick Start Tutorial - walk through of construction of a simple cmd2 based application
- Installation and System Requirements
- Migrating from cmd in the standard library
    - What you have to change
    - What you might have to change
    - What you get for free
    - What features you'll probably want to take advantage of first
- Features
    - Generating output - output, errors, paging, 
    - Argument parsing
    - History
    - The Prompt
    - Startup Commands
    - Shortcuts, Aliases, and Macros
    - Settings - current settings and adding your own
    - Completion
    - Creating Help
    - Working with the operating system - redirecting output, executing commands, editors, paging, etc.
    - Multi-line commands
    - Color
    - Enabling and disabling commands
    - Using the clipboard
    - Python shell and scripting
    - Transcripts
    - Plugins and Hooks
- HOWTO's - A list of recipes/examples for accomplishing common or difficult things, similar to the examples we provide in the source code distribution
    - getting command line arguments from the operating system into your cmd2 program
    - creating a custom help system
    - creating a custom settings system
    - multi-threaded operations
- API Reference (every public function and attribute)

items.title: Encapsulate usage of colorama within ansi.py
items.body:
Now that all of the ANSI color code stuff has been encapsulated within the **ansi.py** module, it would be possible to completely remove the dependency on `colorama`.

If we did this, we could still easily support ANSI escapes codes on Windows 10, macOS, and Linux but would likely lose support for Windows 7 which we probably don't want to do at this time.

However, in order to move in the direction of making it easy to remove the dependency on `colorama` in the future, it would be desirable to limit its usage to a single place - **ansi.py**.

items.title: Remove load, _relative_load, pyscript aliases
items.body:
- Remove `do_load`, `do__relative_load` and `do_pyscript` from **cmd2.py**
- Remove warnings that print when these aliases are called and unit tests that test them.
- Get rid of `try/finally` in `do_run_script` that was added to ensure **load's** warning was printed.
